section_01.section_summary: Jean Honoré Fragonard was born on April 5, 1732, in the town of Grasse, France, to a glovemaker and his wife. Growing up in a picturesque and romantic environment, Fragonard was inspired by the beauty of his surroundings, which would later influence his art. As he grew older, he became aware of the gossip and scandals of the French court, including the rise of Madame de Pompadour, who became a powerful figure in the arts. However, Fragonard's father had other plans for him, apprenticing him to a notary, a path that did not align with the young man's artistic ambitions. Eventually, his notary master recognized Fragonard's passion for art and advised that he be allowed to pursue his creative interests.

section_02.section_summary: At the age of 16, Jean-Honoré Fragonard's mother took him to Paris to meet the renowned painter François Boucher, who advised him to train with Jean-Siméon Chardin to master his craft. However, Fragonard made little progress with Chardin and was sent away, after which he spent time studying and painting the masterpieces in Parisian churches. He later returned to Boucher, who was impressed with his progress and took him on as a student, assigning him to work on decorative cartoons. Fragonard went on to win the Prix de Rome at the age of 20 and later traveled to Italy, where he was influenced by the works of Tiepolo and the Italian landscape, ultimately developing his own unique style. During his time in Italy, Fragonard formed lasting friendships with fellow artists Hubert Robert and the Abbé de Saint-Non.

section_03.section_summary: After spending five years in Italy, Fragonard returned to Paris in 1761, where he found that his master Boucher was struggling with the changing public taste and criticism from the new philosophers. Fragonard initially attempted to paint in the academic style, but soon turned to painting the life and beauty around him, which brought him great success. His breakthrough came with the painting "Les hazards heureux de l'Escarpolette," which showcased his skill in capturing the beauty of nature and launched him into fame. As the favorite painter of the French court, Fragonard became known for his decorative and lively paintings, which reflected the spirit of the age of Du Barry. His art was characterized by its emphasis on landscape and its ability to capture the beauty of the natural world, earning him a reputation as one of the great landscape-painters of France.

section_04.section_summary: During this period, Fragonard was producing a large number of works, including paintings such as "Love the Conqueror" and "The Sleeping Bacchante". His master, Boucher, introduced him to the wealthy and art-loving Farmer-General Bergeret de Grandcour, who became one of Fragonard's most important patrons. Fragonard also received commissions from two female patrons, including the notorious dancer Mademoiselle Guimard, for whom he painted a series of panels, and another woman whose identity is not specified. Meanwhile, the French court was undergoing significant changes, including the death of the Pompadour and the rise of Madame du Barry, a new mistress of the king who would eventually lead to the downfall of the king's minister, Choiseul. Fragonard's career was flourishing, with his paintings showcasing his skill and artistry, as seen in works such as "The Chiffre d'Amour" and "The Fair-haired Boy".

section_05.section_summary: Jeanne du Barry, a young woman from a poor background, rose to prominence as the mistress of King Louis XV of France, but her lack of refinement and taste led her to reject the masterpieces of artist Jean-Honoré Fragonard. Fragonard had painted a series of five canvases, "The Progress of Love in the Heart of Maidenhood," for du Barry, but she found them disappointing and instead preferred the work of artist Vien. Meanwhile, Fragonard's personal life was changing as he married Marie Anne Gérard, a young woman from Grasse, and began to focus on painting scenes of domestic life and rural landscapes. His marriage and new family influenced his art, and he started to incorporate elements of Dutch landscape painting into his work. Fragonard's art continued to flourish, and he proved himself to be an exceptional artist, capable of bringing distinction and style to all his creations.

section_06.section_summary: The French artist Fragonard was at the height of his career, but the country was on the brink of chaos with the corrupt and ruthless leadership of King Louis XV and his mistress, Du Barry. The king's death in 1774 marked the end of an era, and the new king, Louis XVI, and his queen, Marie Antoinette, faced a country scandalized by the corruption of their predecessors. The writings of intellectuals such as Voltaire, Rousseau, and Diderot fueled the growing discontent among the people, who were tired of the privileged class and their abuses of power. Meanwhile, Fragonard was oblivious to the impending doom and was preparing for a second journey to Italy with his patron, Bergeret de Grandcour. This trip would be a welcome distraction for Fragonard, who would eventually face the harsh consequences of the French Revolution.

section_07.section_summary: Fragonard traveled to Italy with Bergeret de Grandcour and his family, enjoying a life of luxury and meeting prominent figures, but their friendship was later marred by a quarrel over Fragonard's sketches. After returning to Paris, Fragonard was granted a studio and apartments at the Louvre, where he lived a comfortable life with his family and sister-in-law, Marguerite Gérard. However, his happiness was short-lived, as his daughter Rosalie died at the age of 18, and the French Revolution began to unfold, marked by the fall of the Bastille and the rise of the National Assembly. Fragonard, a liberal who sympathized with the people's sufferings, supported the Revolution, but the situation soon turned violent and tragic. As the Revolution gained momentum, Fragonard's life and the lives of those around him would be forever changed.

section_08.section_summary: The French Revolution led to a period of terror and bloodshed, with the king and queen being executed and the Jacobins, led by Robespierre, seizing power. The artist Fragonard, who had been associated with the aristocracy, felt unsafe in Paris and eventually fled to Grasse, where he stayed with a friend and continued to paint. During his time in Grasse, Fragonard created several decorative panels and portraits, and even added revolutionary emblems to his host's home to avoid suspicion. Meanwhile, the Revolution continued to unfold, with Robespierre's eventual downfall and the rise of Napoleon Bonaparte, who would go on to become a dominant force in French politics. Fragonard eventually returned to Paris, but as a poor and uninspired old man, his creative spark extinguished by the turmoil of the Revolution.

section_09.section_summary: Fragonard, a renowned painter, struggled to adapt to the changing times and artistic styles after the French Revolution. He continued to paint, but his work was no longer in fashion, and he was eventually forced to leave his lodging at the Louvre due to a decree by Napoleon. Fragonard's health declined, and he died on August 22, 1806, at the age of 74. His family, including his wife and daughter Marguerite Gérard, lived on, with Marguerite having a successful career as an artist. Fragonard's art, along with that of Watteau and Boucher, is now recognized as a key part of France's cultural heritage, embodying the elegance and gaiety of 18th-century France.
